From: David Goodwin <dgoodwin@...>
Subject: Re: [cantera] chemical equilibrium
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=7ovoX8Ala5086nCgtC5biNFW3C9zEpF7TcnEeb9Lk5Pp
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

Solene,

Cantera uses 2 different algorithms to compute equilibrium.  The one 
implemented by class ChemEquil.cpp (and the one used by default if you 
use the "equilibrate" method in Python or MATLAB) uses a form of the 
element potential method.  There are many variations on this basic 
algorithm, and the exact details of the ChemEquil algorithm are not 
currently described anywhere, but can be deduced by studying the source 
code in ChemEquil.cpp.

The other algorithm used is the "VCS" algorithm, which works for 
multi-phase mixtures with condensed phases (unlike the element 
potential method), but is also slower than the element potential 
method.  The implementation of this algorithm is in file 
"MultiPhaseEquil.cpp".

A good book on equilibrium algorithms is "Chemical Reaction 
Equilibrium" by Smith and Missen.  It is out of print, but perhaps you 
can find it in your library.  They define 2 classes of equilibrium 
algorithms - "stoichiometric" and "non-stoichiometric".  Stoichiometric 
algorithms search among a set of states that all satisfy the element 
constraints for the one state that satisfies the conditions of chemical 
equilibrium. Non-stoichiometric algorithms do the opposite: they search 
through a set of states that all satisfy the conditions to be valid 
chemical equilibriium states for *some* set of element mole numbers for 
the one that satisfies the specified element constraints.  Cantera's 
algorithm in ChemEquil.cpp is non-stoichiometric; the one (VCS) in 
MultiPhaseEquil.cpp is stoichiometric.  Cantera's implementation of the 
VCS algorithm follows Smith and Missen fairly closely, but adds a few 
features to handle things like charged species correctly.

Dave Goodwin



On Aug 1, 2005, at 8:38 AM, se_deferrieres wrote:

> Dear Professor Goodwin,
> I'm writing my MSc report on the calculations I did under Cantera and
> I'd like to know which method of determining equilibrium Cantera is
> using.
> Thanks for your help
>
> Regards
> Solene
